dialogues.speaker: TITLE SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: The faces of several young children are presented in CLOS as they walk TOWARD US across a ploughed field. On the SO TRACK, the haunting SOUNDS OF A GREGORIAN FUNERAL CHANT. CAMERA PANS UP to the faces of older brothers and sisters then to parents and grandparents. These are not familiar  faces, but faces from another age, strong and open. All a dressed in the distinctive clothing of the Amish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the last traces of early morning mist another gro of black-clad figures make their way down a lane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Amish buggy, black and highwheeled, stark against the  landscape, appears, a spirited chestnut in the traces. Framed in the glass window of the narrow buggy is the ste figure of an Amish man in black topcoat and flatbrimmed h his bonneted wife in muted colors, the face of a boy, att like his father, peering out. The horse's breath smokes on the frosty air, the buggy CR on its springs, and there's the rhythmic CLIP-CLOP OF HOO on the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER LANE
dialogues.text: Two Amish buggies reach a crossroads, join a procession o three others. They disappear as the lane wends through a  leafless thicket of hickory.

dialogues.speaker: VALLEY
dialogues.text: A BIG SHOT... now the procession numbers almost a dozen  buggies... it is headed toward a distant farmhouse.

dialogues.speaker: BARNYARD
dialogues.text: Where literally dozens of carriages are parked. The horse have been taken from the traces, removed to the shelter o the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the black clad mourners begin to move into the house ( and children presumably first).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coffin has the upper half open. We see that the corps has been dressed in white linen, a piece of white linen  partially covering the bearded face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Partitions have been removed, making the central rooms of the farmhouse a spacious hall. The place is packed, a hun fifty or more Amish, all sitting in absolute silence on r of wooden benches. A wooden coffin rests on a bench in th f.g., and near it the close relatives of the deceased occ a special Place.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL LAPP
dialogues.text: A young woman of perhaps twenty-seven. Her face is pale a drawn. In happier circumstances, although there haven't been too many of late in Rachel's life, we would see a robust, sen woman of full figure, spirit and intelligence. Eight-year-old SAMUEL LAPP flits next to his mother; he w appear stunned, possibly not entirely comprehending event And the patriarch, ELI LAPP; his stubborn, weathered В– y not unkind В– features grief-stricken.

dialogues.speaker: THE MOURNERS
dialogues.text: Their faces...

dialogues.speaker: CLOCK
dialogues.text: As it begins to CHIME nine a.m.

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING PREACHER
dialogues.text: As he removes his hat. As one, the men in the congregatio remove their hats also. Then the preacher begins to speak in a formal German dial SUBTITLES OVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a brother has been called home.  God has spoken through the death of  our neighbor, Jacob Lapp...

dialogues.speaker: THE FAMILY
dialogues.text: Where Rachel, Samuel and Eli are SITTING - SOUNDS of emot and grief not quite suppressed are heard throughout as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...husband of Rachel, father to  Samuel, son of Eli. (and) His chair is empty, his bed is empty,  his voice will be heard no more. He  was needed in our presence, but God  needs such men, too. That one should  be taken so suddenly. Treat sorrow.  Still, we would not wish him back.  Rather we should prepare ourselves  to follow him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHTENING to the Lapps, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mourners have gathered about the grave, standing in  silence as four pallbearers are lowering the coffin into pit. The many buggies are aligned in the b.g. As the pallbearers begin to shovel soil and gravel into t grave, the Preacher begins to read a hymn in German... a  slow atonal litany which seems to hang forever on the fro air.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: TIGHTENING to her as the hymn continues...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the Amish have gathered for the traditional post  funeral, midday meals. Long tables are laden with customary Amishfare... crocks soup, hams, fowl, fried boiled eggs and pickled beets,  preserves and an infinite variety of pies and pastries.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Where she sits among women, accepting their condolences.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL HOCHSTETLER
dialogues.text: A brawny-armed, ruggedly-handsome, raffish looking Amishm There is something atypical about his face a slightly sar set of mouth, a bold eye, a prominent set of jaw. Not exa what old Jacob Ammann had in mind, maybe, but a well set- man nonetheless, and at ease among men. He's among a grou of men including old STOLTZFUS, the local healer, FISHER, BIEILER and Bieiler's stout young son, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lapp was a good farmer. None better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not the man to buy a horse for  you. (and) Hochstetler, wasn't it your father  sold him that horse with a ruptured  testicle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) Told him it was a bee sting made him  limp that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) That horse had one good ball. That's  all it takes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others chuckle. But Hochstetler's attention is still Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: As Hochstetler looms on the horizon, plants himself like tree in front of her. At ease as he was with the men, he's a bit awkward at thi All the women, very much aware of Hochstetler's availabil tune in as Rachel looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was sorry to hear about Jacob. Let  us hope he walks close with God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure he does, Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: FIELDS, LAPP FARM
dialogues.text: It is some time after the funeral and the Lapp family is  hard at work breaking ground for the spring ploughing. Th death of Jacob has increased the work load on all three В Samuel maneuvers a four-mule team while Rachel and old El work nearby, further breaking up the earth. Rachel looks from the back-breaking labor as several figures approach it's Daniel Hochstetler and two of his brothers. Without word they fall in beside Eli and Rachel and take up vario tasks associated with the work in hand. Daniel works close beside Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few BRIEF SHOTS of a lone buggy containing the Lapp fam take us from the 18th century into the 20th century the  reassuring RATTLE OF THE CARRIAGE WHEELS on quiet backroa to the ROAR OF TRAFFIC as the buggy waits patiently for a chance to cross a busy interstate highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge tractor trailer rig hovers over the frail buggy as trots down the interstate. The camera cranes up to reveal procession of vehicles behind the truck for a chance to  overtake it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel Hochstetler moves through the crowd on the plat-fo Rachel turns surprised, as he approaches, a faint color c to her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I was at the feed store. And I  saw your horse, so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an embarrassment between them broken by the arri of the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will come back soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel can barely contain his excitement as he drags at h mother's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quickly, Mother Quickly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel embraces Eli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You be careful out among them English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to Hochstetler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need time, Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel Hochstetler leaps into the driving seat of his ope wagon and with a flick of the reins and a whoop sets his  horse off at a fast trot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ENGINE gives a WARNING BLAST before creeping slowly  forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Samuel spots something out of the window that causes h to light up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Mama...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A road runs parallel to the train track, and Hochstetler his wagon urges his horse almost to the gallop as he atte to keep pace with the train.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: As Rachel smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Samuel cranes to look back, waving, for as long as he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train moves across a broad panorama of fields, dotted with dolls'-house-sized farms and the tiny figures of Ami farmers working their horse-drawn equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the train continues its eastward journey... Samuel sta raptly out of the window at the changing patterns of the  countryside. He points in wonder at a brightly colored ho air balloon as it drifts slowly over timbered hills... he looks unsure as the pattern of field and wood gives way t suburbs, bustling shopping centers, restaurants, car lots and fast food outlets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the train travels past dilapidated row houses, streets choked with cars and the gutters with filth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Samuel is staring out the window with some confusion, almost apprehension:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this where we're going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not. We're going to  Baltimore. It's much nicer in  Baltimore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Rachel draws her son closer, turning her back on the  window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel is in a line at one of the counters. The plain dre of the two Amish В– particularly Samuel's black coat and В– are drawing curious stares.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: He's uncomfortably aware of the shy looks and giggles of little girl about his own age, standing in line with her  parents at the next counter. He edges away from his mothe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Samuel comes upon a figure garbed in a long black froc coat and flat-brimmed hat... the man's back is turned, co from appearances, be an Amishman. Samuel stares... A beat, the man turns to face Samuel and discover that he is a Hasidic Jew.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: As he reacts.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO TICKET COUNTER
dialogues.text: As Rachel's turn arrives. The TICKET SELLER glances up an she shows him her ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a ticket to Baltimore. Where  is that train, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delayed three hours. You'll hear an  announcement when it's time to board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to go without his hat, but Rachel collars him a puts it on his head.

dialogues.speaker: MEN'S ROOM
dialogues.text: As Samuel enters. It's a long row of sinks, urinals, and stalls... Samuel s before one of the urinals В– a long, trough-like affair w water drizzling down the rear porcelain panel. It's set a little high for Samuel, and it is making GLUGG FLUSHING NOISES that are, at least, intimidating. Samuel  stares for a moment, then turns, looks toward the stalls, stoops to see which are empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beneath the row of doors we can see no feet visible. Samu is alone in the restroom.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: As Samuel proceeds along the row of door, finally selects stall near the end. He enters. As he does so, a heavily  bearded youth in a dirty sweatshirt enters. With some urg he removes small notebook from his pocket and places it b a paper towel dispenser. Suddenly he glances up. Two other men have entered the men's room; one is a large BLACK MAN in a three-piece suit under an expensive, overc His PARTNER is a Caucasian in designer jeans, half boots a short leather jacket. They advance on the young man with unmistakable menace. The young man whirls in terror; his two assailants lunge him... a savage, wordless struggle ensues in the close  confines of the lavatory.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL'S STALL
dialogues.text: As the struggling men bounce off the door of his stall... can see their feet under the edge of the door.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO FIGHT
dialogues.text: As the struggle builds to a climax... ends with the young man stiffening with a grunt, his face draining of color. The two attackers step away, the blade in the black man's hand bloodstained. His partner stares at what they've  accomplished with a stunned expression:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young man's hand comes away from his belly covered wi blood. He stares at it, staggers toward the sinks. Finally his  bloodied hand reaches to smear at his face in the mirror. Then he collapses to the floor. The black man motions for his partner to watch the door,  then quickly reaches up and removes the notebook from beh the dispenser.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL'S STALL
dialogues.text: As he edges open the stall door a crack. Over his shoulde we can see the black man, his BACK TO US, rifling the  backpack. But beyond him, in the mirror on the far wall, catch sight of the black man's face.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: As he stares out the narrow crack. A beat, then he closes the stall door.

dialogues.speaker: STALL
dialogues.text: Samuel tries to make the latch work, but it's warped and  won't fall closed.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK MAN
dialogues.text: As he checks the notebook before placing it in his pocket His partner is covering the door, an automatic in his han The black man makes for the exit, then on second thought, glances at the row of stalls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All quiet, but...

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The black man whips out a .38 caliber revolver, and, star at the near end, starts pushing open the stall doors.

dialogues.speaker: SAM'S STALL
dialogues.text: As the black man approaches, Samuel working desperately o the latch. At the last minute he finally wedges it in.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK MAN
dialogues.text: He elbows Samuel's stall... the door won't open.

dialogues.speaker: SAM'S STALL
dialogues.text: Fighting back panic, Samuel has retreated as far as he ca

dialogues.speaker: BLACK MAN
dialogues.text: As he gives the door a kick. It holds. He swears under hi breath.

dialogues.speaker: SAM'S STALL
dialogues.text: In desperation, Samuel does the only thing he can think o he slips under the partition into the neighboring stall t black man just checked out. But he loses his hat in the  process. His hand snakes back INTO FRAME to snatch it jus as the black man gives the door a ferocious kick that  splinters the lock and nearly takes it off its hinges. He framed there, the big muzzle of the .38 revolver looking  down our throats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As his partner snaps from the doorway:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you come on, for Christ's sakes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat, then the black man holsters his weapon, turns to  follow the partner out.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SAMUEL
dialogues.text: As we hear the SOUND OF THE TWO MEN EXITING the lavatory. long beat, then Samuel opens the stall door a crack.

dialogues.speaker: HIS POW THROUGH DOOR
dialogues.text: Samuel's own face reflected in the blood-smeared mirror.. then PANNING DOWN to the still figure of the young man ly in the crimson pool of his own blood on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: BENCH WAITING ROOM
dialogues.text: Samuel sits close to his mother, his face pale, his eyes  staring. Rachel holds his hand tightly in hers as the torsos of va police and officials pass through foreground, occasionall obscuring the lonely couple. There is considerable ECHOIN NOISE as commands and requests mingle with the CRACKLE OF TWO-WAY RADIOS.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: The diffused shape of faces behind the frosted glass of t Men's room door, which is pushed open to reveal, JOHN BOO who comes striding through to be momentarily lost in the  crowd of police, reporters and others. He is about 40, wi a rangy, athletic body. Behind him comes CARTER, Book's b partner В– about five years younger than Book. Book is we a suit, Carter is much more casually В– almost disreputab dressed.

dialogues.speaker: BENCH
dialogues.text: Little Samuel watching Book, back to crowd of police, as  Book questions an old black CUSTODIAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You found the body?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh uh. Not me, daddy, I just reported  it. It was the kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'n hell do I know what kid? The  kid in the funny black threads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worry-eyed, still staring straight ahead. Then his eyes m suddenly to his left.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK'S LEGS
dialogues.text: Coming in at full stride, then stopping.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: He doesn't raise his eyes... just looks at the legs. And, slowly, the legs begin to bend at the knees. We see Book' belt buckle, then his big pistol in its holster, then his face. He stares at Samuel for a moment, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As his face breaks into a big grin, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, kid.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Immediately alarmed, intervening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want of my son?

dialogues.speaker: THE SCENE
dialogues.text: As Book takes out his wallet, displays his shield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a police officer. I'm going to  have to talk to the boy. What's his  name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel. Samuel Lapp. (then, quickly) But what happened here is none of  his affair. My sister is expecting  me... our train is leaving soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There'll be another train. (turns to Samuel) The man who was killed tonight was a  policeman, Sam. It's my job to find  out who did it. I want you to tell  me everything you saw when you went  in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stammers) I saw him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam looks at his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd you see, Sam? The man on the  floor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... I saw the man who killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book stares at him in surprise, speaks over his shoulder Carter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody know about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't even know about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to Sam) Okay, Sam. Can you tell me what he  looked like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (groping, touching  his clothes and  pointing at Carter) He was... like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Black... I understand. What else,Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat, then Sam crosses quickly to Carter, Book's rather slightly built partner:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Zwartich, like him В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book frowns, puzzled:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try that one again, Sam В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel gives his mother a helpless look; exasperated, Rac intervenes with Book. She glances at Carter:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rachel takes Book aside, and in a low voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zwartich. It's the way we say...  dwarf. (glances at Carter) Not like him... very big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book nods, starts to turn back to Sam. Just then a commot off screen catches his attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Capt. TERRY DONAHUE, Chief of Homicide, striding pas the crowd of journalists and TV crews... brushing off  reporters' questions and snapping orders to the aides he' got in tow:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to aides) Close it all down... I want a man on  every exit... I want the lab in here  now! (to Book) And I want to talk to you, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Book steps aside with Donahue... In the b.g. Rachel mo protectively to Samuel's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is homicide В– not Internal  Affairs! So why are you behaving  like you own this case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were running Zenovitch... That's  all I can tell you. But I want it,  Terry. (then) I've got a call into Schaeffer.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL / SAMUEL
dialogues.text: They can't help but watch the confrontation between Donah and Book... although they're keeping the volume down, it' obviously intense and angry:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed) Momma... are they angry with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reassuring, but hardly  in her own mind) No... No. It is just the English  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donahue has lost the confrontation; he gives Book a smile

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to think about coming back  to Homicide, Johnny... Stick with  Internal Affairs and you're not gonna  have any friends left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles right back) I'll buy a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book emerges from the terminal, looks about him, then cro to a big Mercury Sedan which is parked nearby. Two men si in the front seat. Book crosses to the driver's side and  opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go get a cup of coffee, Stan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver, a uniformed policeman, glances at the man bes him who nods in agreement. He gets out and Book gets in b the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book sits next to SCHAEFFER, a surprisingly kindly lookin man of about fifty. Schaeffer is a Deputy Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How reliable is this kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zenovitch was about to deliver a  list of names tonight В– street  chemists... the guys processing this  P2P into speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So one of them got to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still convinced there's a  link to the department?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there isn't I've just wasted the  last six months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the problem. We need results.  The press is driving us crazy over  this P2P thing. Calling us the 'speed  capitol of the country'. You know  the sort of thing. It's getting  political. The Commissioner's getting  very uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Amish boy saw him, Paul. I'll  make it, but Set Donahue and the  Homicide Department off my back or  they'll blow the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When word gets out that Zenovitch  was a cop, all hell will break lose.  You've got 24 hours. That's all I  can give you. 24 hours on your own.  After that the case and the witness  go back to the Homicide Department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Tell you what... why don't you and  that blonde В– what's-her-name В– come  over for dinner Sunday. How 'bout  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's-her-name moved to Buffalo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Well, anyway, don't get crazy. (dismisses him) I'll do something for Zenovich's  wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book drives around 13th Street, a ravaged corridor betwee neon lit restaurants, bars, porno shops and darkened  storefronts. Carter sits beside him, Rachel and her son in the back se looking out at the assorted array of desperate characters huddled in doorways or wandering aimlessly about. On the  POLICE RADIO a description of the cop killing is BROADCAS EVERY FEW MINUTES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got there late, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just find Coalmine. (beat) Listen, Zenovich made a mistake. You  didn't let anybody down. It happens  В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) It won't happen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you taking us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're looking for a suspect. We've  reason to believe he's still in the  area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no right to keep us here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I do. Your son is a material  witness to a homicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand, we have nothing  to do with your laws!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't surprise me. I meet a lot of  people like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book decides to try contrition:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. It's not a joke. Listen,  I know a little about the Amish. I  know this has to be an ordeal for  you; and I'm really sorry you an  Samuel got involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel shoots a look at Book then mutters something to hi mother in German. She responds in the same language. Book frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to know who you are. Your  name. I told him we don't need to  know anything about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book eyes Samuel:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book. John Book

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book's car stops, and from out of the shadows darts a wiz little MAN. He looks about before crossing to the driver' side window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book lowers the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy, where's Coalmine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little man stares at the weird-looking couple in the  back seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you got there, the Salvation  Army?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coalmine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try "Happy Valley".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book's car pulls up outside the bar and he and Carter get out, and move swiftly inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty black faces stare as the police enter. A hush falls the group. Book and Carter spot their man at the bar and  move up either side of him. They've moved carefully to th point... no mistakes. From the back, the black man they'v approached certainly looks like he could be the man who d the killing of Zenovitch. And, as Book and Carter make th move...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Book and Carter explode through the door of the bar,  violently propelling Coalmine along with them. Now we see Coalmine is not the killer. As Book and Carter escort Coalmine out of the bar a polic squad car pulls up, its headlights shining into Book's ca An alarmed Rachel holds Samuel close as Book forces Coalm face down next to the car window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put some light on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cop pulls out a flashlight, begins to play the beam ove Coalmine's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; to Samuel) Look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy as Rasputin on speed and booze, Coalmine glares at  Samuel inside the car: Samuel, white-faced, finally shakes his head in the negat Coalmine tries to twist free of Book's grip. Book snaps, slams Coalmine's skull into the window edge, finally crus his face up against the front window. His face takes on a grotesque shape against the glass. Carter restrains his  partner and Book cools down. Coalmine is led stumbling aw by the uniformed police. This sudden show of violence has horrified and angered Rachel, and she glares at Book as h gets back in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Book, you listen to me! I will  have no further part in this, nor  will my son! As God stands between  us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book sighs, starts the engine and moves off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book pulls up outside a hotel entrance as a uniformed DOO moves to open the rear door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel and Sam recoil as the Doorman opens the door. He i puzzled by the sight of the reluctant guests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! We do not stay in hotels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book and Carter exchange a glance.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: An attractive woman in her early thirties in robe and sli stares in disbelief as Rachel and Sam file into the house This is ELAINE, Book's sister. She stops Book as he tries follow Rachel inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you do this to me tonight?  I told you I had company

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. It's important.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RACHEL
dialogues.text: As she glances in a doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a shambles, with dirty supper dishes piled sink, the table littered with empty beer cans.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RACHEL
dialogues.text: As she hustles Samuel along.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK / ELAINE
dialogues.text: Book frowns:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Timmy and Buck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upstairs, asleep. Where'd you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a man here and the kids  are upstairs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's none of your goddamn business!  So keep your goddamn holier-than- thou mouth shut! (and) Anyway, they like Fred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sure, Fred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine looks like she's going to blow again, then decides it's pointless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are these orphans, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're Amish.

dialogues.speaker: GUEST ROOM
dialogues.text: Samuel is asleep in one twin bed in a tiny, cluttered roo Rachel, in a plain nightgown, is preparing to climb into other one. Off screen we hear a DOOR CLOSE, presumably Book leaving. beat, then Elaine opens the door and looks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat) John said you're Amish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blankly) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods and goes. Rachel crosses to Samuel, sits on the bed. Samuel looks u at her bleakly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are English. They don't  understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish dawdie was with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swallows) I know. Sleep now, Liebchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her hand on his forehead, closes his eyes. she  frowns, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carter exits the cafe carrying burgers, donuts and a coup of beers. Book wakes from a brief nap as Carter gets into the car. Book chews into his burger while Carter takes a doughnut. Its clear they've worked through the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine's house is situated on the corner of a row of terr which stretch into the distance on both sides of the stre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Samuel comes out of the guest room in his night-shirt, turns up the hall and opens the door to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's not the bathroom; it's Elaine's bedroom. She and FRED are tangled in the sheets, furiously making love. El gasps, Fred manages to grunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong door, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Samuel quickly shuts the door. A straight-faced beat;  then, barely suppressing a giggle, he hurries on...

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: As Rachel appears in the living room entry. Samuel is sit on the floor with two boys of about his own age, watching television. They're eating cold cereal out of a box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some artless Saturday morning cartoon.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RACHEL
dialogues.text: As she frowns, watching her son and the other two staring hypnotically. And...

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: It's later in the morning now, as Elaine, a bit blearily, appears in the entryway, stares in groggy disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her oldest boy and Samuel are busily washing the windows  while her youngest is pushing a carpet sweeper. The TV is off.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO ELAINE
dialogues.text: As she stares.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Rachel is standing in the middle of the now immaculate ki finishing a brisk mop of the floor. The coffee is perking Elaine appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mutters) Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel turns cheerily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helplessly) You didn't have to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to. you were kind to take  us in last night. (and) Anyway, I needed something to do. I  was so angry with your brother. He's  so... agaanisish!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aganishish? Yeah, that sounds like  John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a seat at the table, still shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute. I'll pour you some  coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not carrying a bullwhip...  how'd you manage to put my kids to  work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) I made it a contest... the one who  does best gets his cereal back first. (and) Children like to help... they only  need to be kept after a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel means no harm by this, but Elaine's eyes begin to  storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, is that so? (and) No offense, lady, but I'm not so  sure I like the idea of your coming  in here and turning the place upside  down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel's smile fades at Elaine's trembling outburst:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, I didn't mean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abruptly Elaine rises and snatches the mop from Rachel's  hands. She mops furiously as she Continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know exactly what you meant! Listen,  maybe I'm not a world-class housefrau,  but maybe I don't have time to polish  the goddamn china and keep after the  kids! (and) It's none of your business, but I  don't happen to have a man around  here full time. So I sell cosmetics  in a goddamn drugstore and sometimes  I can even pay the rent on time! So  maybe I'm not Mary Poppins, but maybe  I don't need to have it jammed down  my throat like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finishes the floor, hurls the mop aside with a CLATTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is that clean enough for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel is speechless, Elaine is on the point of bursting  into tears. At which point Fred appears at the entry in h undershirt, taking in the sparkling kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Elaine... Somebody die and  leave you a broom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a politic observation on Fred's part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blurts) Go to hell, Fred!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, bursting into tears, she flees the kitchen. Fred sta after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's bugging her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unperturbed, he crosses to the counter and the coffee pot letting his eyes take in Rachel's full figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rachel comes in with Elaine's coffee, closes the door  behind her. Elaine is lying across the bed, sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought your coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a seat next to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I didn't mean it that  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment, Elaine starts to pull herself together:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. (and) Look, I shouldn't have blown my top.  It's like... somehow... I've let  everything get away from me. And you  sort of made me face it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the cup, sips the coffee. Rachel smiles at a pr thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred. The way he looked when you  screamed at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disparing) God, Fred...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At home you'd never hear a woman  scream at a man that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just wouldn't. It's not the Amish  way. (then) But I think it would have done me  good if I could have screamed at  your brother last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I don't know what's going on  or how you got mixed up with him,  but don't you let that self-righteous  son of a bitch push you around, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book glances irritably at Rachel:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The problem is I don't happen to  think my son should be spending all  his time with a man who carried a  gun under his coat and goes around  whacking people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book gives her a look:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whacking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly) Yes. And I also want to leave this  city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, I'm trying to get this  over with as fast as I can. But Samuel  will probably have to come back and  testify.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do not go into your courts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People who don't go into our courts  when they're told to sometimes go  directly into our jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel glares at him and the ride continues on that chill note for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm genuinely sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snaps) No you're not В– (off his look) You're glad, because now you've got  a witness. (and) I heard the other police talking  last night. (and) They don't seem to like you very  much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kid a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glances at him) I would not be too sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel has been glancing at Book; finally he says somethi to his mother in German. Book gives her an inquiring look

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says you look very tired. I thought  the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not a good tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a 'good' tired. Tired is tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't bother to explain; Book settles even deeper i his funk as Samuel glares at him with hostility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel sits with Book at a desk, Rachel just behind. They are looking at a police line-up of known black drug-deale Samuel shakes his head В– another negative. Book winks, slyly reaches into a pocket, produces a yello gumball. He surreptitiously shows it to Samuel, gives him inquiring look. It's a peace offering. Samuel grins, nods imperceptibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Book rolls the gumball down the table to Samuel. But j as Samuel is about to cover it with his hand, Rachel reac over and plucks it off the table. She shakes her head at  Samuel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rachel) Just wanted to see if you were on  your toes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book, Sam and Rachel sit on a park bench eating a lunch o hot dogs heaped with kraut. Book watches with amusement as Samuel wolfs down his lunc Rachel eyes him a beat. then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your sister said you don't have a  family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She thinks you should get married  and have children of your own. Instead  of trying to be a father to hers.  Except she thinks you're afraid of  the responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book gives her a look:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes. She thinks you like policing  because you think you're right about  everything. And you're the only one  who can do anything. And that when  you drink a lot of beer you say things  like none of the other police would  know a crook from a... um... bag of  elbows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book is staring at her. Rachel nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that's what she said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then Samuel belches with huge satisfaction, drawing  looks from Book and a couple of passersby. Rachel smiles  proudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good appetite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel sits uneasily in the outer office, one or two poli clerks eyeing her curiously. A sign on the desk reads  "Narcotics Division." Rachel cranes forward trying to peer through a partially  open door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of Narcotics Detectives are interrupted in mid  conversation by the opening of the main office door. They stare in considerable surprise.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN BOOK
dialogues.text: Standing in the doorway, holding little Samuel by the han

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon, gentlemen. I'd like you  to meet Samuel Lapp. We'd like a  little help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Narcotics Detective enters the room laden with several  volumes of mug shots. He puts them on the desk beside a  similar book which Samuel is intently studying. Sam sits the chair cushions in a big swivel rocker. The Detective, SGT. KAMAN, eyes Book a little suspiciousl internal affairs officers are not greeted warmly by the  working policemen in any department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a Sgt. Carter on the phone  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book gets up and moves to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, Captain, don't want to rush  you, but I'm gonna need these files  back in a half hour. We got a lot of  work to do round here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men leave. Samuel looks about before hopping off perch and following the direction taken by Book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through glass partitions we can see Book on the telephone a cubicle of an office. Samuel has drifted out of the office and is idling amid t bustle of the squadroom. He crosses to a glass case which holds a collection of pl and framed newspaper accounts which denote instances of  outstanding duty and achievement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Samuel moves along, only half interested in what his e are taking in, not really old enough to comprehend anyway Until suddenly he freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enlarged, prominently displayed. The headline reads: "Div Chief McElroy Honored For Youth Project". Accompanying th item is a large sidebar mug-shot of McElroy В– clearly th black man who murdered the young cop in the train station men's room.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SAMUEL
dialogues.text: He stares, transfixed. A long beat, then Book, lowering himself to one knee next Samuel, ENTERS FRAME. He's watching Samuel, knowing from the boy's expression t they've found their man. Samuel slowly raises his hand to point at the photograph. Book gently takes the boy's smal hand in his, concealing the accusation from watchful eyes He smiles gently at the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel is curled tight in her corner of the front seat ho Samuel close. Book glances at her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you arrest that man? Are  you protecting him because policeman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snaps) Listen, I'm the cop that polices the  police. I'm not in the business of  protecting crooked cops. (eases up) I'll make an arrest when I know  everybody involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why would they murder...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because В– somehow В– they knew I was  getting close. (and) Look, it's narcotics... They make  dope out of chemicals... they sell  it on the street for millions of  dollars. They'll do anything. (and) And they can get away with it because  they're cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat, then) I'm afraid. I'm afraid for Samuel. I  want to go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be safe. You don't have to  worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says nothing. Another beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, they're thinking as long as  they keep the killer out of Samuel's  way, we can't make an I.D. There's  no way they can know Samuel saw that  photograph, so he's safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances at her, but she continues ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it. You will be safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Rachel explodes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes! Of Course. Why shouldn't we  feel safe in a city where the police  are so busy killing each other!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door of Schaeffer's upper-middle class home is  opened by his wife MARILYN. She knows Book and is surpris and delighted to see him. In the background daughter KATH is visible. Schaeffer himself appears and Book is welcome inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaeffer passes Book a drink. Book is excited, animated... the hunter, after a long cha closing on his quarry:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was McElroy, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaeffer gives him a sharp look:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last guy I would have figured. But  he's part of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you don't have any doubts  about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I did, I'd have kept my mouth  shut... (and) It fits, Paul... Fifty-five gallons  of P2P confiscated four years ago...  Guess who was in on the collar? Mac. (excited, explaining  the thing eagerly) He salts it away somewhere... he  knows the stuff is potent, but the  street chemists haven't figured out  how to process it. But they do now. (and) And now the stuff is worth five-grand  a pint and there are a lot of pints  in a fifty-five gallon drum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Who else knows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Okay, what are you going to need to  clean it up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More people... Gotta pick up where  Zenovich left off. People from outside  the department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Maybe the Bureau. Or those bastards  at Treasury. I'll take care of it. (then) I hate this shit, Johnny. You cut  their balls off for me. I'm counting  on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaeffer pours himself another drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your first move?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (expels a breath) A hot shower... I haven't changed  clothes in two days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book slams the front door of his car, checks it for being locked, glances at a roiled newspaper in his hand (the sp section of the Inquirer), starts across the parking lot t his apartment, walking as he keeps glancing down at the s section. He comes to a sort of crosswalk, stops, reads, s to take a step... and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McElroy, smiling nicely, starting across toward him from other side of the parking lot crosswalk

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BOOK
dialogues.text: Freezing, eyes widening. Utterly surprised and caught.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Still smiling, he brings up his right hand out of a shopp bag (which he appeared to be carrying) В– letting the sho bag fall away as he does so В– revealing a five-inch barr Smith and Wesson .357 blue finish revolver with a silence Without hesitating, coming right on, still smiling, he FI once.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: Already starting to leap away to one side, he is hit, dri into a half-turn. He clutches at the wound, as:

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Coming right on, FIRING again... the pistol's report a  WHOOSHING, like the opening of a bottle of cheap champagn And McElroy still smiling as:

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: Hit... a grazing near-miss this time, but enough to send  Book down hard and grasping.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Lowering the pistol alongside his leg, as two MEN, barely taking notice of anything, cross with their backs to Book toward McElroy. He smiles at them.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: Down, muttering CURSES.

dialogues.speaker: THE SCENE
dialogues.text: As McElroy walks past Book, drops the pistol to the pavem keeps on going... and is gone.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: GROANING in pain, beginning to try to crawl crab-like. An we HEAR В– from the agonized recesses of Book's Dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else knows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the lights of an oncoming car В– going very slowly, on way to a parking space В– sweep over him and we HEAR it c to a sudden, squealing stop. Book is already trying to ge to his feet... now succeeds, lurching into a swaying stan using an adjacent car for support. OFF SCREEN we HEAR a c door slam, and footsteps hurrying in our direction,  accompanied by excited voices. Book HEARS, turns to face oncomers,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fat, middle-aged MAN has approached to within some feet Book, looks on edgily:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, buddy, what's the score? Little  too much to drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book stares at him, then looks down at his belly.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK'S WOUND
dialogues.text: As Book removes his hand we can see one of the bullets st him low in the side, just below the ribcage... the other  just above it (but this one inflicting only minor damage)

dialogues.speaker: THE SCENE
dialogues.text: As the man stares:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn, buddy. You better get to a  hospital! (and) Here; I'll give you a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to approach, but Book shoves him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No hospital!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now the man's WIFE is hovering at a safe distance:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him alone, Henry! If he wants to  die in the street, that's his  business!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the man is not content:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Romona! Will ya look at  that blood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book has tried to lurch toward his car; the man tries to  intercept him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, buddy... you're gonna bleed  to death!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book whirls on him, his service revolver in his hand poin squarely at the fat man's face:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quavering) I told you, Henry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book doesn't trust himself to speak, but the .38 is  sufficiently eloquent for the circumstances, He stares at the fat man another beat, then hesitates, turns, starts b toward his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Book's car wheels somewhat erratically through traffic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book has a gym bag open on the seat next to him, is stuff a tshirt under his belt to staunch the blood. And...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he's awakened by the RINGING bedside telephone. He sna on a lamp... He's instantly awake, not unused to such rou in the wee hours. A woman sleeps beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: He's at an n.d. pay phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen carefully, I wrote the Amish  woman's name and address on my desk  calendar, I want you to lose it for  me, Now. Tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about? What's happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. I'm not going to be around  for a while. I'll call you when I  can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed) Johnny, what the fuck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hard) Listen to me В– Schaeffer's part of  it. Maybe at the top of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a stunned silence at the other end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... I can put it all together  when I get back, 'Til then, you know  nothing, understand? Business as  usual...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) I hear you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Good. Take care of that woman's name  for me. And watch your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the door opens and Elaine switches on the light, rousi Rachel. Elaine looks haggard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's John. He says you have to leave  now. He says it's urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves the room as Rachel instantly awake, moves quic to rouse Samuel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine is outside the bathroom listening to instructions  from her brother. From inside we hear the SOUND OF RUNNIN WATER. Elaine is puzzled but also senses the urgency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put my car in the garage and close  the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, I don't understand any of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snaps) You don't know anything... borrowed  your car. Didn't say why. And you  never heard of that woman and her  boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, why?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) Just do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book looks at himself in the mirror, his face is pale and drawn. He examines the wound, a cleanly drilled hole through his right side, just under the rib cage. The wound continues bleed as he binds a towel tightly about him, before putti his shirt back on. He then carefully wipes away any traces of blood on basin with tissues which he flushes down the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he drives across town. Samuel is curled up asleep, his head on Rachel's lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you taking us now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't wait until morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book gives her a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insistent) What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Book, glancing in his rearview mirror, tenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In it we can see a police car coming on fast, with lights and SIREN.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Rachel eyes Book warily. A beat, then the police car WAILS past. Book expels a bre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said we would be safe in  Philadelphia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel looks away, speaks almost sarcastically, MUTTERING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinner un Narre... ["Kinner un Narre saage die Waahret"  В– "Children and fools say the truth"  В– Amish expressions]

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: ANGLE PAST Book's desk calendar. Carter enters in the b.g crosses quickly to the desk. He snaps on a light, thumbs page of the calendar. Frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel's name and address scribbled on a page of the cale

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of plainclothesmen have paused outside the door give him a look. Meets their eyes. They move on. Carter shakes it off, goes. And...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As light colors the eastern horizon, Book is crossing int Lancaster County. Book glances at Rachel; she's asleep. He coughs wrackingl hurting... cinches the belt of his overcoat even tighter. And...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming up the long drive.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: As the car pulls up in the barnyard and Eli crosses to it Suddenly the car door flies open and Samuel jumps out, ra across the barnyard to hurl himself into the old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rachel steps out of the passenger's side, Book remains seated. He lets his eyes travel around the farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay for awhile. Rest. I'll make  coffee and breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Samuel? Will you come  back to take him to trial?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book starts the engine:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) There isn't going to be one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel stares at him, not sure what he means. Then backs  away, closing the door. Book begins to turn the car aroun in the barnyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Eli crosses to Rachel, his arm around Samuel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name is John Book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli is about to inquire further when Samuel cries:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momma В– look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They glance in the direction Samuel is looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car has failed to take a bend in the road and is now  bouncing across an adjoining ploughed field. It's knocked over a tall birdhouse by the roadside. The car finally co to rest against a bank of earth.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RACHEL
dialogues.text: She stares...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Samuel races for all he's worth across the field,  negotiates the creek via a fallen log В– Rachel, now, als running toward the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli works fast harnessing his mules to an open wagon. He  hops up to the front seat and urges them to trot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see that Rachel has made Book as comfortable as possib in the front seat of the car and is packing the wound und his trenchcoat with material ripped from her apron.  Momentarily he comes awake:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But John... why didn't you go to a  hospital?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no doctor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered) But why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gunshot... they'll file reports...  they'll find me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book reaches up to grip her arm fiercely:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when they find me, they'll find  your boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slips under again. Rachel stares at him, realizing the price he's paid in returning them to safety. She reaches out, touches him gently. But the moment is broken by...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Eli reins up in the springwagon. He climbs down, cross to glance into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the English dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks dead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And together they begin to lift Book from the car and pla him in the back of the springwagon. And...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Eli is looking out a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Amish buggy coming up the drive, past Book' s car.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Where Book lies on a bed. Rachel is bathing his wound wit warm water from a pan. Eli appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stoltzfus is coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel looks at him, nods. Eli frowns at Book's holstered pistol lying atop his neat folded clothes on a chair near the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That has no place in this house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up the pile of clothes and the pistol and place them in a chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will go when he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Samuel comes in with old Stoltzfus and Stoltzfus's tee son, LEVI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming, Stoltzfus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stoltzfus's eyes have gone to the bed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the English is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stoltzfus runs his fingers lightly over the vicinity o Book's wound:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel... burning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stoltzfus, in his shirt sleeves and concentrating migh moistens his fingertips with saliva, continues the  examination. Finally he steps back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man should be treated in town. (indicates) The bullet entered there... and came  out there. But there is the danger  of infection, and he has lost a great  deal of blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel looks at Stoltzfus, then turns away, torn by her  dilemma. Her eyes fall on Samuel. Gently she ushers him from the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go help Levi with the car, Samuel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes the door after him, then turns to face Eli and Stoltzfus:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he must stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stoltzfus gives Eli a puzzled look. And:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you hear Stoltzfus? What if  he dies? Then the sheriff will come.  They'll say we broke their laws В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll pray that he doesn't die! But  if he does, then we'll find a way so  no one knows!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel, this is a man's life, we  hold it in our hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know God help me, I know that,  Eli. (then) But I tell you that if he's found  here, the people who did this to him  will come for Samuel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel beseeches them helplessly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else can we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levi has hitched Eli's mules to the rear of Book's car an is towing it up the drive toward the barn, with Samuel  catching a ride on the bumper.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Where she's waiting with the big barn doors thrown open. the mules tow the car in, she closes the doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stoltzfus and Levi are about to go: Stoltzfus turns to Rachel:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make a poultice... three parts milk,  two parts linseed oil... for the  infection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll send Mary by with some teas I will brew myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stoltzfus turns to Eli:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lapp, I'll have to speak with the  diener on this matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) As you see fit, Stoltzfus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rachel enters, turns up a kerosene lamp which is burni low at bedside. She's carrying the poultice Stoltzfus ord Book's brow is beaded with sweat. Rachel seats herself next to the bed, strips away the swe soaked sheet. Her eyes take in his bare torso, and we sho get the feeling that there's rather more male animal on  display here just now than she's quite comfortable with. She begins to apply the poultice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Book rouses to semi-consciousness, in his delirium he  recoils with alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right! You have got to lie  still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book stares up at her without recognition, but some of wh she says seems to penetrate. He quiets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soothingly) Yes, much better...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Book lapses back into sleep. Rachel hasn't removed her hand from his chest. Abruptly she does so. She finds herself wondering about this man lying before h so suddenly a part of her life. She notices details; brui scars, the knuckles are hard, grazed, a tattoo on one  shoulder. While lost in this reverie, the delirious  Philadelphia policeman begins to mutter. Incoherently at  first, then the words take shape В– swear words; curses; this and that; shit; etc. Rachel rises abruptly, her chee coloring, as the barrage of language pours from his mouth She beats a hasty retreat closing the door swiftly behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on the phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like we're going to need some  help from you folks down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where an UNDERSHERIFF is on the phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...want to help any way we can, Chief,  but you got to understand we've got  upwards of seven thousand Amish over  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's just Lancaster County.

dialogues.speaker: SCHAEFFER
dialogues.text: Who is trying to control his impatience:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got the woman's name, Sheriff.  Lapp. Rachel Lapp. That should  simplify your work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Undersheriff frowns. He doesn't like being talked dow to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about an address?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah... no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowns) Maybe a road or route number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Undersheriff is not impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Problem is, Chief, 'bout every third  Amishman around here is named Lapp.  That or Yoder. Or Hochstetler. (and) Chief, if the Amish have taken your  man in, I wouldn't want to hang from  a rope until you find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaeffer is tight-lipped with contained fury:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sheriff. It's been an  education.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. A beat; the man is a study in frustration. T he glances up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing in his doorway are the two plainclothesmen who  spotted Carter in Book's office in the earlier scene. And

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bright, sunny afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: Where he's leading a team of horses to the barn. In the b three buggies are parked in the barnyard, traces empty.  Visitors.

dialogues.speaker: SICKROOM
dialogues.text: Where Book lies in the bed. His fever seems to have subsi He's coming awake, tries to focus on the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PANNING the four men in Amish black who are standing arou the bed looking down at Book, muttering among themselves German. These include TSCHANTZ, the district bishop, a hawk-nosed sterneyed old fellow; Stoltzfus, a deacon as well as a he and two preachers, ERB and HERSHBERGER. Eli stands somewh apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another moment of silence, then Book opens his eyes. Tschantz rumbles in German. SUBTITLES OVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Stoltzfus, another Lazarus to  your credit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was touched by God's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tschantz grunts, motions, for the other clergy aside with him. Rachel enters briskly with a steaming pot of tea and a cu smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book stares at her, then at the old bearded gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (closing his eyes) Who are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The leadership of our district...  the diener. Bishop Tschantz is the  one with no hair on top. They decided  to come and see you for themselves.  Except Stoltzfus, of course. He came  the first day. I think he saved your  life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have something to drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel brings him tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does anybody know I'm here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only the elders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have I been here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat) Listen, thank you. Thanks for  everything. But I've got to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowns) But you can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to rise, falls back faint. Rachel rearranges the sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See. Anyway, you don't have any  clothes on. And besides that, Bishop  Tschantz wants to talk to you when  you feel better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elders appear to have concluded their conference, and are filing out. Stoltzfus pauses at bedside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rest, Mr. Book. That's the ticket.  And drink my of my tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes. Book is still fending off the dizziness. Rachel  puts the teacup to his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him his tea stinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) You tell him. When you're able.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks like he's about to drop off again. Rachel rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the door) We're all very happy that you're  going to live, John Book. We didn't  quite know what we were going to do  with you if you died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That penetrates for a moment just before Book slips into  sleep again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the rather worrisome Hershberger frowns:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but a gunshot wound. Very serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not the first time we have  done this. In the Englischer war of  the revolution, old Elmer Miller's  grandfather took in gunshot English  soldiers. (a tad of pride) Saved them, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all nod. What Tschantz says is well known. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, he should be among his own  people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel enters on this last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll leave as soon as he is able.  He already wants to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hershberger gives her a gloomy look, turns to Stoltzfus:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long will that be, Stoltzfus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) A month. Maybe less. With God's  healing love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaeffer is knocking at the front doors. A beat, then El opens it cautiously, peers out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half fearfully) Did you find him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly her eyes blaze, she starts to close the door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then go away, you bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaeffer quickly В– but gently В– prevents her from shut it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine, I've come to apologize for  Lt. McElroy. He overstated the  department's position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) He accused John of taking kickbacks.  And you know В– anybody who knows  John В– knows that's a goddamn lie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smoothly) Of course, Elaine. But as long as  there's any question, better Johnny  should come back and clear his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cuts in) Better you should get off my front  porch before I get my mace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine, I don't want to have to take  you in for questioning. You've got  his car, you were the last to see  him В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clipped) I don't know where he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... if you had to guess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McElroy watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a final exchange between Elaine and Schaeffer. Ela forces the door shut. Schaeffer turns, walks slowly to hi car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Schaeffer opens the door, climbs in, sinks wearily int the seat, beside McElroy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She say where he is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think she knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaeffer is staring grimly ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Carter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tight. But I'm working on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lean on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REESTABLISHING, and TIGHTENING to the upstairs sickroom w where a lamp dimly burns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Samuel comes in with a fresh bedpan. Book is lying asl on the bed. Samuel puts the bedpan down, checks to make sure Book is  indeed asleep, then quietly crosses to the foot of the be and opens the clothes chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book's big .38 revolver lies holstered atop his folded  clothes. Fascinated, Samuel picks it up, admiring the heavy burled pistol grips. Unable to resist, he starts to remove the w from the holster, then pauses to steal a look. OFF SCREEN

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: His eyes are open and watching Samuel icily, which gives boy something of a jolt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mutely, Samuel hands Book the pistol from arm's length. H looks on as Book takes the pistol out of the holster, sho the boy another look, then snaps open the cylinder and sh out the heavy, copper-jacketed bullets into his palm. He  snaps the cylinder closed again, then nods to Samuel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy edges closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever handle a pistol like this,  Samuel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swallows) No pistol. Ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
