dialogues.text: Tell you what В– I'm going to let you  handle this one. But only if you  promise not to say anything to your  momma. I've got a feeling she wouldn't  understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) Okay, Mr. Book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book smiles. Then he gives the boy a playful, John Wayne- tough guy wink as he cocks and uncorks the pistol,  demonstrating the action. He finally hands it over to Samuel, butt first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy tries to imitate Book's one-handed expertise, but his hands are too small. Book smiles. Samuel finally manages to get the thing cocked, using two hands, and Book reaches over to guide the muzzle away so  that it's not pointed at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to point that at people  you just started calling by their  first name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel levels the pistol at the door and, just as he snap the trigger, Rachel enters, pulls up short in some dismay find her son has a gun pointed at her. Samuel blanches an Book winces, knowing there's heavy weather ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snaps) Samuel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel quickly hands the pistol back to Book, who holster it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait for me downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel quickly exits, and Rachel angrily advances on Book

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Book, I would appreciate it if,  during the time you are with us, you  would have as little to do with Samuel  as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody meant any harm. The boy was  curious. I unloaded the gun -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the gun. Don't you  understand... It's you. What you  stand for. (and) That is not for Samuel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book looks at her thoughtfully. Rachel softens a bit:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, it has nothing to do with  you personally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her the holstered gun and the loose bullets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it up someplace Samuel can't get  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat, then Rachel, takes the pistol and starts to go. B stops her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel glances back at him, smiles and nods. And...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book's holstered gun and bullets at center table. Eli sit on one side, a chastened Samuel on the other. Rachel look on from the b.g. Eli knows that this is as important a dialogue as he will ever have with his grandson: at issue is one of the centr pillars of the Amish way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gun В– that gun of the hand В– is  for the taking of human life. Would  you kill another man? Eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel stares at it, not meeting his grandfather's eyes. leans forward, extends his hands ceremonially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you take into your hands, you  take into your heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat, then Samuel musters some defiance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would only kill a bad man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a bad man. I see. And you know  these bad men on sight? You are able  to look into their hearts and see  this badness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see what they do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he meets Eli's eyes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have seen it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli expels a deep sigh; then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And having seen, you would become  one of them? (intent... gesturing) Don't you see...? The hand leads the  arm leads the shoulder leads the  head... leads the heart. The one  goes into the other into the other  into the other... And you have  changed, and gone amongst them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks off, bows his head for a moment. Then he fixes boy with a stern eye and, driving he heel of his palm fir into the tabletop with enormous intensity:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wherefore come out from among them  and be ye separate, saith the Lord!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating pistol;  continuing from  Corinthians 6:17) "And touch not the unclean thing!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His intensity tinged with righteous anger, he is hugely  impressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book stands near the door to the kitchen, and has heard m or all of Eli's words. He turns, and painfully makes his into the washhouse, moving quietly, hoping no one will co out from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel harnesses up the family mare, and backs her into t traces of the buggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book stands at the window in a worn robe. Below, through window, we can see Samuel and Eli in the barnyard. A beat then Book crosses impatiently back to his bed, sits down, picks up a dog-earred copy of The American Dairyman. Ther a stack of well-thumbed farm magazines and copies of The  Budget (the Amish newspaper) on the bedside table. There's a knock. Rachel enters carrying a pile of clothin She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enjoying your reading?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very interesting. I'm learning a lot  about manure. (eyes the clothing) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your shirt and jacket are still  stained with blood. I have them  soaking.You can wear these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She passes the clothes to Book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It's good that someone can have  the use of them. Besides, in your  clothes you'd stand out to strangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She continues, cheerfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should tell you these do not have  buttons. (shows him) See? Hooks and eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wrong with buttons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buttons are Hochmut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hochmut?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vain. Proud. Such a person is  Hochmutsnarr. He is not plain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Anything against zippers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost blushing) You make fun of me. Like the tourists. Driving by all the time. Some even  come into the yard. Very rude. They  seem to think we are quaint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quaint? Can't imagine why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the nearest telephone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Telephone? The Gunthers across the  valley. They're Mennonite. They have  cars and refrigerators and telephones  in the houses even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'd want a public phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel's face clouds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... the store at Saltzburg... (then briskly) But you won't be going to Saltzburg  for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Stoltzfus said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in) I know what he said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can go with Eli. He's taking  Samuel to school. But you'll have to  hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel turns to leave when Book calls her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to look at him. It's the first time he's used h name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli calls impatiently from the buggy. Samuel sits beside  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up now, John Book!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel washing dishes turns on hearing Book enter. She la out loud at the sight of him in his Amish gear, and right so В– the pants are highwater, the hat low-rise, the jack ill-fitting. Book looks self-conscious, even a little sheepish. Outside another SHOUT from Eli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book looks embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My... eh... gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smile fades from Rachel's face as she reaches up into cupboard. She passes the gun in its holster to Book. He  fastens it about him. The contradiction of an "Armed Amis increases the awkwardness between them. Book turns his ba to her and checks the weapon. He turns back to her smilin in an odd way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The... bullets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. The bullets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes them out of a disused coffee jar, passes them t Book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (attempting a joke) Not much good without them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel sits between Eli and Book. Both men stare straight ahead. Eli looks particularly stern. It's pretty clear he doesn' like this Englishman wearing the clothes of his faith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With awave Samuel runs into the schoolyard to join his  friends. A teacher begins ringing a bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book on the telephone waiting for his call to be answered He looks about him В– several Amish and Dithers mingle in shop. Book-has gotten a coke from a machine, seems a bit self- conscious shout it sips at it surreptitiously... A voice  comes on the line; it's that of Book's partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny! Where the hell have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind. I'm coming in to take  care of business. How hot am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low, urgent) Too hot. Don't do it. Don't come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Johnny, don't do anything  stupid. You couldn't get within a  mile of Schaeffer right now. So stay  put... Stay in touch В– I'll let you  know when maybe it makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat as Book considers that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (edgily) You hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) I hear you. I'll stay in touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's more like it. (and) Where are you at, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book allows himself a small smile, regarding his Amish im reflected in the window of the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where I'm at is maybe 1890.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomprehending) Say again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make that 1790.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. A beat, then he stares toward the door of th store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book works on his car. The battery has gone flat and he's trying to charge it up by running wires to a battery moun under the front seat of the Lapp buggy. Eli stands at the barn door staring at him, again the  disapproving look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you are well enough to do that  thing, you can do work for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book is genuinely apologetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I'm sorry. Hope you don't mind  me plugging in to your battery. Mine's  dead... How can I help? What can I  do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe milking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes Eli) Milking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cows. You know, cows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, you start tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Book lies asleep. A beat, then Eli comes in carryin lamp. He pauses a moment to peer at the sleeping figure with  undisguised anticipation. Then he gives him a jarring thu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (briskly) Veck oufl. Time for milking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book comes groggily awake as Eli exits. He gropes for his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It reads 4:30 a.m.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BOOK
dialogues.text: As he stares at it in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the milk herd of half dozen or so cows ambles in with  Samuel prodding them along, headed for the milking stalls Book looks on in the lamplight, nonplused.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL
dialogues.text: Where he's pitching hay into the cow's feed-troughs.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK, ELI
dialogues.text: Where the old man is showing Book how to milk a cow by ha We see Rachel watching from the milkhouse door (steam fro scalding milk cans rising behind her).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, firm twist and pull, eh? (and) Right. Now you try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book gives him a look, takes over the milking stool. The shoots him a rather skeptical look over her shoulder. Boo bends to his task.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you hear me, Book? Pull! You  never had your hands on a teat before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) Not one this big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli unexpectedly finds this hilarious, cackles, gives Boo comradely, man-of-the-world thump on the shoulder that ja him. Then he moves off. Book bends to his task, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grinning, giggling, covering her mouth with one hand. As he pours a pail full of milk into a large, stainless s milk can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the milk herd is released back into the pasture. Book  crosses into the f.g., stares OFF SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And dawnfire etching the hilltops. The BELLHOUSE behind t house, the sun reflecting from the heavy bell beneath its small roof.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BOOK
dialogues.text: Something in him can't help but respond to the beauty. A beat, then he blows on his hands, rubs them briskly tog against the morning chill, and turns back to the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is later in the morning. Rachel comes out onto the por tosses a pan of dirty dishwater off onto the grass, looks toward the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli and Book standing in one of the open doorways, lookin in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE FAVORING Luke, one of Eli's team of fine mules as S opens the stall gate. The beast is skittish, obviously  afflicted with something of a behavioral problem. But he allows Samuel to lead him out.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK, ELI
dialogues.text: As Samuel brings Luke out. Eli is now harnessing the othe mule of the team to a large manure-spreader. But as Luke  nears Book, his eyes widen and he shies, almost hauling S off his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed) Careful, son В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book moves to Samuel's aid; a gesture which proves a seri mistake. Luke erupts into a SCREAMING, bucking cyclone. S В– who no doubt has been here before В– dives nimbly for as a flying hoof nearly takes Book's head off. Then Eli hustles into the fray, pushing Book aside as he  BELLOWS belligerently in German at the rearing animal. Fi he gives Luke a swat upside the head that seems, somehow, have the effect of quieting the beast instantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel gives the shaken Book a look:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Luke. He doesn't like  strangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still shaken) You don't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli leads the pacified mule back to the traces, grunting Book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have to teach you mules, too, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book collects the pieces of the birdhouse which his car  knocked down the day of his attempted departure. He pause as a figure approaches. We recognize Daniel Hochstetler,  Rachel's would-be suitor. He heads for Book with an outgo smile and outstretched hand. Here's a likable man who lik people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning. Book, is it? You are  the Yankee they talk about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I was the English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: English, Yankee. It's the same. My  name is Daniel. Daniel Hochstetler. (sizes up his clothes) You look plain, Book. (grinning) Very plain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book is not particularly amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to see Rachel Lapp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hochstetler gives Book a powerful clap on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (genially) You bet. you take care of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hochstetler heads for the house. Book stares after him wi some interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rachel emerges from the house to greet him. She also  catches sight of Book and she pauses, a shadow of confusi crossing her expression for an instant. And Hochstetler doesn't miss it either. Then she gives her suitor a genuine smile of welcome.

dialogues.speaker: HOG PENS
dialogues.text: Book, having gathered up the pieces of the bird house, is headed toward the outbuildings, passing by hog pens. He  glances toward the house:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Rachel and Hochstetler are sitting in a porch swing sharing a pitcher of lemonade.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BOOK
dialogues.text: Thoughtful... He glances at the hog pen as a huge sow SQU and angrily noses her young ones away from the trough so can feed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pigs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book works on repairing the broken birdhouse when Rachel  enters.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: He uses a drawknife on a piece of 2x4, with some obvious  expertise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli is a fine carpenter. Best in the  district. He and his father built  the big house themselves forty years  ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? (and) What happened to Hochstetler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had some lemonade and he left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A real fireball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel smiles. Book crosses to a workbench and selects an tool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know carpentry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did some carpentry summers when I  was going to school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else can you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (really annoyed) I can whack people. I'm hell at  whacking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whacking is not of much use on a  farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now hold on. There's a lot of people  who think being a cop is a legitimate  job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm sure it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns, starts to go. Then turns back, eyeing his make garb:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight I'll let out those trousers  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stifling a smile, she goes. HOLD on Book a beat, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli is seated at the head of the table, Book opposite Sam and Rachel. The table is piled high with an incredible am of food. Eli eyes Book cagily, waves his fork at him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat up, Book. What's the matter with  your appetite?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess I'm not used to so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snorts) Not used to hard work. That's what  makes an appetite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book swallows that one. With difficulty. Rachel intervene

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli, John is a carpenter. (conciliatory  afterthought) As well as being a fine policeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh? Well then, maybe he can go to  Zook's barn-raising, eh? See how  good a carpenter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book can't refuse the challenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... You may not be well enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll drink some more of Stoltzfus'  tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rachel, lamp in hand, walks up to the barn. She looks to find Book tinkering with the battery hookup to the Lap buggy. He glances up as she enters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she sets her lamp down near the one he's using.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) When will you be going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not long... A few days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another beat as Rachel watches him... Book, checking out battery power, hits the radio В– and suddenly from the  Twentieth Century comes the sound of one of its major  inventions В– rock and roll. It fills the barn, but Book turns up the volume a click m even and, eyeing Rachel, starts moving with the beat. It' his culture, coming through loud and clear, as incongruou as it all might seem with the tough Philly cop decked out Amish. Rachel can't help but laugh... Sensing her response, Book sweeps her up and they boogie in the lamplight, Rachel  alternately protesting and laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like it... Don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel, confused, protests:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... You just stop В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she doesn't really want to. Book grins:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mock alarm) Next thing you know you'll be off  drinking beer and racing motorcycles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it goes on... Rachel alternately protesting and laugh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Eli suddenly appears. He glowers for an instant,  thunderstruck, then BELLOWS:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel!

dialogues.speaker: THE SCENE
dialogues.text: As Book and Rachel's dancing comes to a sudden halt. Both turn, look at Eli. Rachel regards him level-eyed, without discernible alarm. Book, looking a bit sheepish, goes ove turns off the radio, as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in the dialect) What is this? This Myusick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book hesitates, then starts to say something:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not her fault. I В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he gets such a look from Eli that he turns, goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in the dialect) How can this be? How can you do such  a thing? Is this plain? Is this the  ordnung?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have done nothing against the  ordnung.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in the dialect) Eh? Nothing? Rachel, you bring this  man to our house. With his gun of  the hand. You bring fear to this  house. Fear of English with guns  coming after. You bring blood and  whispers of more blood. Now English  music... and you are dancing to  English music! And you call this  nothing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have committed no sin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in English) No sin? Maybe. Not yet. But, Rachel,  it does not look... (tone softening... in  the dialect) Don't you know there has been talk?  Talk about you, not him. Talk about  going to the Bishop. About having  you... shunned!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is idle talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in English, pleading) Do not make light of it, Rachel.  They can do it... quick! Like that!  And then... then I can not sit at  table with you. I can not take a  thing from your hand. I... I can not  go with you to meeting! (the old man almost  breaks down as, in  the dialect) Rachel, good Rachel, you must not go  too far! Dear child!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel is annoyed В– also touched, no doubt, by the old m plea В– but irked by his condescending tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly stern again) You are acting like one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will be the judge of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fierce as a prophet) No! They will be the judge of that!  And so will I... if you shame me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blinking a tear now,  but meeting his gaze) You shame yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And shaken В– but proud and erect В– she turns and walks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carter sits, Schaeffer prowls... slowly, letting silences grow before he strikes again with another softly-snarled  question or statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd lie to protect him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cool) Probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaeffer snaps around, glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You admit you're lying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes head) I admit I don't know where he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the first one he'll contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighing) He's got my number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaeffer stops, stands in front of Carter, takes a deep  breath... suddenly smiles. And is abruptly (as he is capa of being) the man of charm and gentlemanly reason. He eve CHUCKLES as he begins:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's funny. I know he's hiding  somewhere with the Amish, I know it. (a quick glance at  Carter) Can you imagine John Book at a prayer  meeting? Our John Book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaeffer CHUCKLES again, looks hopefully again at Carter Carter looks back, stony-eyed. Schaeffer makes another ab shift in form... but still speaks softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either you're a member of the club  or you aren't, Elton. (he nods his head, as) Tell me what you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I know, Paul, is... (nodding his head) He's going to take you out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Book pauses by the barn door, glances over his shoulde

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With trace horse harnessed... Samuel and Eli loading  provisions into the buggy, standing down by the house.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BOOK
dialogues.text: As he goes into the barn. Book approaches Luke's stall warily... and as he does so temperamental mule, reacting to form, starts to skitter, hooves CRACKING against the walls of the stall. Book flin Book starts to talk gently to the animal:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, you nasty son of a bitch,  we're going to be friends whether  you like it or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, summoning his resolve, he carefully opens the stall gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Luke eyes him balefully, Book reaches into his pocket, brings out some lumps of sugar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See... Sugar. You like sugar, don't  you for Christ's sake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, keeping a mistrustful eye on Book, Luke condesce to eat. Book nods with satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel has entered the barn, is watching Book with a puzz expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book turns, grins with some pride of accomplishment!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won him over just like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. (and) But I hope you have a lot of sugar. (then, going) Eli is ready to go to Zook's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then Luke skitters impatiently... Book gives him a  nervous look; one last tentative pat as Luke eyes him  skeptically, then closes the stall gate and turns to go:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BIG SHOT... it's early morning as the Amish buggies are  arriving at the Zook farm for a barn-raising. In the b.g. we can see big stacks of lumber all around th construction site where a couple of dozen men have begun  raising the main supports on the already laid foundation. Elsewhere, long tables have been set up and women are  spreading them with cloths, setting out big tanks of hot  coffee and cold lemonade for the men,

dialogues.speaker: LAPP BUGGY
dialogues.text: As Eli, Book, Rachel and Samuel step down, Book eyes the  construction site.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait here 'til I find a gang you can  work with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes. Book glances around as even more buggies arrive more workmen and their families climb out. Eli appears with Hochstetler in tow. Hochstetler's broad  face breaks into a grin:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book! Good to see you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pumps Book's hand with his usual vigor, smiling a gree and pleasantry to Rachel. She looks on, amused. Hochstetler gives Rachel a look, and we realize that his  showing up just now to appropriate Book was no happenstan And Book realizes it as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli says you're a carpenter, Book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No matter. Come with me. We can always  use a good carpenter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that he throws a huge arm around Book's shoulder and ushers him away. Rachel calls after them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK / HOCHSTETLER
dialogues.text: As they move off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your hole is healed, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gives him a look) Pretty much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hochstetler nods with satisfaction:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Then you can go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the morning progresses: ...Book and Hochstetler sawing and augering out heavy tim on big sawhorses. There's an unmistakable atmosphere of  competition between the two men, which doesn't go entirel unnoticed by the half-dozen or so other young men on the  gang. ...or, indeed, by Rachel; in fact, she seems В– without l on it too heavily В– to be measuring the two men as the m progresses, and she occasionally passes within proximity them. ...Eli and a couple of other elders prowling the job with sheaves of hand-drawn sketches under their arms, supervis the construction. All around them the structure is rising with remarkable rapidity. ...Rachel, where she's helping the women set out the huge noon meal. Other women are sitting on benches in the b.g. knitting or doing quiltwork. ...Samuel, where he's banging away with a hammer, with a  group of boys his own age. Elsewhere we see little girls  "botching" (a hand-clapping game played to German rhymes) ...The very elderly; sitting on the grass or in wheelchai in the sunlight, looking on В– the old men kibitzing in G the women gossiping. Until...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the barn-raising with the noon sun high overhead... at least a hundred and fifty men are swarming over and about the barn framework... ...some aid the rafters, some hauling lumber to the job,  others sawing, hammering, drilling, joining, planing and  what-all... so many that the barn seems almost to be rear up before our very eyes. And there isn't a power tool in  sight.

dialogues.speaker: WOMEN'S AREA
dialogues.text: As Rachel crosses near the benches... we can see other wo eyeing her, whispering among themselves, some tittering.  Rachel ignores them. She joins the stoutly amiable Mrs. Yoder from the funeral sequence earlier. The older woman is emptying a big pan o fried chicken into serving platters. She smiles, obviousl liking Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone has an idea about you and  the English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of them charitable, I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly any of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book and Hochstetler astride the roofbeam studs, holding  them together prior to nailing them to the roof-beam. The are, therefore, crotch to the mast and facing one another way out at the far end of the roof. Suddenly, as Hochstetler raises his hammer, the studs sta to part, threatening to de-ball the both of them. Hochstetler drops his hammer, grabs both sides of the roo with incredible brute strength, and, literally, pulls it  back together. Book stares at Hochstetler with nothing short of awe. Hochstetler, straining and grinning, looks to Book:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nail it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he does nail it while Hochstetler, grinning and holdi looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The barn is done, the workmen climbing down from the raft It's late afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: He hesitates. His face is pale and covered with sweat. Th exertion of the day has taken its toll. He's in danger of fainting and is some forty feet above the ground. But he' determined it won't happen, determined that he won't fall nor will he humiliate himself by calling for help. Hochst guesses the situation. He moves beside Book, claps an arm about him, says nothing, doesn't even look at Book. From  below, someone TELLS them to hurry up. Hochstetler shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We admire our work!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moment passes for Book, and he's okay. Hochstetler re his supporting arm. Book looks him in the eye, nods his  appreciation almost imperceptibly. Hochstetler wants no  thanks, and Book knows it. Hochstetler gives him a resoun SLAP on the back, and starts climbing down. Book follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gathering has congregated to hear Bishop Tschantz off up a blessing on the new barn.

dialogues.speaker: CONGREGATION
dialogues.text: PANNING the faces as they listen to the heavy German word rolling out over the still evening air. Book stands a little to one side of the Amish. The prayer he cannot share with them. Rachel is aware of this, feels something of his emotion. She looks toward him, then she closes her eyes and drifts away from him, into the soothi prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book stands outside, listening to the NIGHT SOUNDS. He tu walks up toward the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book takes a seat in a chair, SIGHS, looks toward the nig sky. There is a SOUND, but it's a moment before he turns his e toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel standing there in his nightshirt.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: As Book leans forward in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Sam...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I want to say a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting up) What's that, Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy hesitates, holds for a time, then suddenly darts  across to Book, wraps his arms around him, hugs him tight then breaks away, turns and runs hack into the house, lea the door open behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking after the boy, genuinely moved. After a moment, h speaks softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same to you, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After another moment, he gets up, moves to close the door that Samuel has left open behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the lighted/shadowed area outside the door. He comes the door, starts to close it, then hesitates, looks into where the light is coming from. He looks down the corrido The light is obviously coming from the kitchen. He speaks softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. Book steps inside, pulls the door shut behind  him, moves down-the corridor toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Rachel, dressed only in a plain cotton camisole, is pouring a pail of steaming water into a tub. She replaces the pail on the stove, turns and slips out o her camisole. Naked, she folds the garment across the bac of a chair. Then she pauses, containing a startled intake of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gleaming bottom of a large copper skillet hanging ove the stove with other cookware, we can see Book's image  reflected there, framed in the kitchen doorway.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Rachel hesitates for a moment В– and in that moment she m a choice. Slowly she turns, to face him, without shame, meeting his eyes. And for a moment she attempts something: a look, a flash eve... a lovely, heartbreakingly innocent effort to becom for an instant, a woman of Book's world.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: As he stands in the doorway, willing himself to leave, un to make it happen. And suddenly the moment has passed. Rachel lowers her eye picks up the camisole, covers herself with it without put it on, looks away.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: TIGHTENING to him, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Rachel is scattering feed to the chickens. A beat, then Book approaches from behind her. A moment, a she senses his presence. Book watches as Rachel begins to gather the eggs, placing them in the fold of her apron. When he speaks, he speaks softly, and she pauses in her w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes very still, but keeps her back to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If... we'd made love, then, I couldn't  leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lowers her head slightly, but remains turned away fro him. Book continues to stare at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lapp carriage on a winding lane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel is driving, Book sitting next to her. Samuel is in the back, looking out the rear window and not paying any  attention to the adults. A beat, then a large produce truck roars past them. It's Book can do to keep from flinching. Rachel stares straight ahead. Book glances at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I ought to learn to drive this  thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Pick myself up another useful skill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Rachel can't help but smile. She looks at him. And...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see the Lapp buggy approaching a rural intersectio another buggy approaching at right angles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rachel eyes the other buggy through the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel, who is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel checks out the buggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like Hochstetler's mare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Lapp buggy passes the intersection and the Hochste buggy swings in behind them. Then the Hochstetler buggy,  coming on at a faster clip, starts to pass the Lapp buggy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rachel waves at the occupants of the other buggy; Dani returns her greeting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing her) Uh oh, they're leaving us behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel gives him a look, and... gives the reins a flick В the race is on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hochstetler has a couple of older folk on board, together with his young sister В– at first they're not aware of th race, until Daniel can contain his excitement no longer a gives his horse a couple of whoops. The buggies are neck neck, and the older people are not protesting loudly. It's all Book can do to refrain from grabbing the reins o Rachel, but she's something of a horsewoman and finally s gains the edge and pulls ahead of Hochstetler, to the che of Samuel and Book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a Saturday afternoon in the tourist season, and they everywhere В– taking shots of anything Amish. There's a R YOUNG ELEMENT amongst them who are making their presence  fast, and generally making a nuisance of themselves. Book and Rachel get out of the buggy. Samuel stays inside the crowds make him nervous. A huge tourist bus billowing smoke pulls up nearby. Rachel enters the store, but before Book can follow he's  stopped by a TOURIST LADY with an instamatic camera... Sh waggles the camera at him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I... ah, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Lady, if you take my picture, I'll  rip your brassiere off and strangle  you with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tourist Lady stares at him in stunned disbelief, her  grin frozen on her face. Then she begins to scuttle back  from whence she came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel is browsing among the stocked shelves in the compa of a young Amish woman, Ellie Beiler. Rachel is carrying  Ellie's tiny baby, and the infant is getting as much atte as the shopping. Book is standing at a wall pay phone in the b.g. We TIGHT to him, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Elton Carter, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat, then we hear the FILTERED VOICE of the Philadelph Police Department switchboard:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a member of the family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I'm a friend of his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Last night Sergeant Carter  was killed in the line of duty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book hangs up. His breathing is thrown out by the shock o the news and he takes a couple of deep breaths to regain  control. He hesitates, unsure of his next move. He makes move away, then he turns back, finds more coins and dials second number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaeffer's wife answers the phone; she is momentarily  shocked. She calls for her husband, then makes polite conversation

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul Schaeffer appears, slightly irritated at being calle away from the Saturday afternoon game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering mouthpiece) John Book!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take it in the study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaeffer takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can hang up, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR the click of the other phone,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You made a mistake, Paul. You  shouldn't have taken Elton out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) How bad did Mac get you? We figured  pretty bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. I'm going to live a long  time. That's what I called to tell  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Johnny В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might want to pass it along to  Mac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgently) Listen to me, Johnny. Come in! You're  out there all alone... We're getting  close... real close... Maybe if you  listen to me for a minute we can  work something out so you can come  in В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've already got something worked  out. (and) Be seeing you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book hangs up the phone and the dead CLICK registers on  Schaeffer. Book has gripped the phone so tightly that it takes a sec to unclench his fist. Then it takes something else to res his first impulse, which is to smash out at something...  Training. Get it under control. Deal rationally with the  situation. He straightens his jacket, wipes the sweat/tears from his eyes, turns and walks stiffly out of the Saltzburg Genera Store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book, as Rachel eyes him. She has noticed his changed moo but doesn't ask about it. He stares straight ahead, obliv to the surroundings of the street, now crawling with tour and traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The buggy turns into the side street. Some hundred yards  ahead another buggy is stopped in the middle of the road several youths gathered about it. A pickup truck is stopp facing the buggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rachel approaches the scene, slowing down and finally  stopping. Rachel is at first puzzled, then makes a small face, look at Book. Rachel puts a restraining hand on Book's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do nothing. This happens from time  to time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She senses him about to get out, grips his arm tightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not our way, John. We'll have  nothing to do with violence! John!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book shakes free, gets out and slowly walks toward the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hochstetler and his family sit, impassive, ignoring vario jeers and taunts from the English lads В– various jokes a them being dirty etc. One jabs an ice cream cone into  Hochstetler's forehead, which leaves a curious white circ on his forehead. Another fools about with the horse causi it to shy. A third notices the slow, sure, approach of Jo Book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here comes another one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book stops, his path blocked by the third youth. The yout flicks off Book's hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) You're making a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hochstetler calls from his buggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything is all right, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the youth) Pick up the hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The youth momentarily unsure В– something about Book's to of voice. The youth does pick up the hat, crumples it, st on it, and puts it back at a crazy angle on Book's head. pause, then Book explodes. The kid never knew what hit him or where it came from, he hits the road surface already unconscious. A second youth grabs Book from behind. A mistake. Book is smashing into  him, spatters of blood from his nose flying in all direct He's hitting too hard, too often. It's Schaeffer he's hit Hochstetler is pulling him away, Rachel is there too. A c is gathering, but as suddenly as it began it's over. Book shakes Hochstetler off him, straightens his hat, and in a kind of daze, begins walking past the scene in the direct of the Lapp farm. The youths are picking up their wounded, helping them bac to their truck, aided by none other than Hochstetler. An LOCAL addresses Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never seen anything like that in all  my years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering) He's from... Ohio... My cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll, them Ohio Amish sure must be  different. (addresses a gathering  crow) Our Lancaster brethren, they just  don't have that kind of fight in  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, lost control of himself. He...  will be repentant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rachel) You're Rachel Lapp, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Samuel! We're going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A second man calls from the pickup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid's nose is broken!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take him up the hospital. Good- day to you, Mrs. Lapp. (he shouts after her) This ain't good for the tourist trade,  you know! You tell that to your Ohio  cousin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Rachel is already steering past the scene and followi the by now distant figure of John Book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book comes out of the carpenter's shop carrying the repai birdhouse on its pole in one hand, a shovel in the other. Rachel is shepherding the milking cows toward the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should not bother with that  birdhouse. (a beat) If you're leaving tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving tonight. (and) I'm going to need my clothes. And my  gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods, looks away... looks back at him twice in glance There is a moment when it appears she might either bark a him or begin to weep. He waits. When she does turn to him she speaks softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a time when I thought you  might have stayed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitating... then) There was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a time when I would have  welcomed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (asking) I was being foolish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (and) I was being unrealistic. Even thinking  about living this life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so sure of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you? After today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost conceding it,  but... her voice  rising a bit, annoyed) I'm not so sure of anything as you  are, John Book. You could live this  life if you wanted to bad enough. (a beat) Just as I could live yours!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost groaning) Oh, come on, Rachel. No way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is always a way! But you are  such a... a Glotzkopp you cannot  see! You'd rather go back to that  city! To nothing! No woman! No  children! No land!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (now getting annoyed) Land! Are you crazy? I'm no Amishman  and I'm no farmer! I'm a cop. That's  what I know and that's what I do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you do is take vengeance! Which  is a sin against heaven!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your way, not mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's God's way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well in the City of Philadelphia,  God needs a little help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has offended her, immediately knows it, but can't brin himself to make an instant apology. But he's chewing on i when she takes the moment unto herself. She pulls herself up, speaks with great dignity:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could never love a man who was  so... little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her, sad-eyed, his anger ebbing and gone,  realizing that he'll never meet a finer woman... never ev get close to such a one. He appears to start to speak, bu then does not. She turns, moves away a few steps, stops, looks back at h she holds for a moment, blinking tears, then speaks with  some difficulty, emotion welling in her words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other night... when you saw me  after my bath... I... I tried to  look as I thought you would want a  woman to look. (sadly... but with a  slight, proud lift  of chin) I am sorry... that I did not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds for an instant, then turns and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: Looking after her. A face full of loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli is lighting the lamps. Samuel reads a book at the kit table. Rachel moves slowly to the sink and begins washing few dishes. She looks out the window. CLOSE on her face, a strange expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The distant figure of Book working on the birdhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Rachel's hands, lifting items slowly up and of t water to the draining board, where she places them carefu down. She shakes the water off her hands. CLOSE on her face, still staring fixedly out the window. speaks without turning around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli, would you see Samuel to bed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man glances at her; this is not their routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the rapidly fading light, Rachel walks slowly toward B CLOSE on her face, staring straight ahead toward Book. ANGLE on Book, CLOSE. He turns and watches Rachel's appro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light now nearly gone, the NIGHT SOUNDS beginning, as Rachel reaches Book and they embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book and Rachel in a passionate embrace, sink to the stil warm earth and make love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING an all-night cafe in the early hours of the  morning. TIGHTENING to the bleakly lighted windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A booth, where Schaeffer and McElroy and Fergie, a Lancas County Undersheriff and his SHERIFF В– an expansive polit type В– are seated. The Undersheriff eyes Schaeffer narrowly. The Sheriff has county map spread out on the table, amid breakfast dishes pointing directions to Schaeffer:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There... White Oak Road a couple of  miles before it ties into two-twenty- two. Got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it. We owe you one, Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My man Holmes here put it together.  Fine officer, Chief. He spoke to the  doctor at the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Undersheriff Holmes and I have talked  on the phone. (nods at Holmes) Good work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you don't want us to post some  backup units?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we need any help, we'll give you  a shout. I'd like to slip in there  quiet, then get out before we attract  any attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Schaeffer and his men are climbing into their car. Hol and the Sheriff watch after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll take a drive over that  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let 'em be. It's their dirty laundry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Holmes pauses to watch Schaeffer's car pull out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the first light of dawn on the eastern horizon,  Schaeffer's car approaches along the lane, pulls into the Lapp driveway and comes to a halt. In the b.g. we can make out the farmhouse and outbuilding HOLD as Schaeffer, McElroy and Fergie step out of the car They break out short-barreled twelve-gauge pumps, start T CAMERA, spreading out as they turn up the long driveway.. figures of ominous intent striding through the misty dawn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GOING WITH the trio of gunmen... McElroy, breath smoking the chill, eyes the terrain:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weird, man. No fuckin' electricity.  What do you figure they plug all  their shit into?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't have any shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Eli is getting into a heavy coat, preparing to go o the remains of the hearty morning breakfast are on the ta Rachel is beginning the dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book and Samuel are starting the morning milking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli is preparing to extinguish the lamp when suddenly the kitchen door is kicked open and McElroy and Fergie weapon leveled, burst in. Eli reacts with angry shock as Schaeff enters: Rachel is, for a moment, terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fergie) Outside В– (to Mac) Check out the rest of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to Eli, who is standing in the middle of the roo Schaeffer flashes his badge:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're police officers. We're looking  for a fugitive, John Book. He's living  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have nothing to say to you. Get  out of my house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You speak English. Good. Now listen  В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recovering) No, you listen. Get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady, I'm here to help you. This man  is very dangerous. An armed criminal. (ingratiating) He's got a gun, hasn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no right here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McElroy re-enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not in this building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Eli) All right, where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Eli SHOUTS: It's deafening. Probably the loudest noise Eli has ever made:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Book!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McElroy whips around, smashes Eli on the temple with the  butt of his shotgun. Eli crumples to the floor. Rachel  SCREAMS, runs to Eli.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book and Samuel in the milkhouse. They've heard Eli's out Book moves to the window, looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About halfway between the barn and the house. He turns fr glancing back toward the house (having heard Eli's shout) and starts again toward the barn. Gun at the ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Book REACTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel kneeling next to Eli, wiping at his bruise with a  damp cloth. Schaeffer looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might have killed him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to McElroy) Find Fergie, check the barns. I'll  watch these two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McElroy nods, moves outside, turns toward the barns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book still at the window, Samuel now beside him, trying t get a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning, mind racing) It's them, Sam. (he bends to the boy,  takes him by the  shoulders) Now, Sam, listen to me and listen to  me carefully. Listen to me as you  never listened before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Are they going to kill you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me, Sam! I want you to go  across the new corn to Stoltzfus'.  Run as fast as you can. And stay  there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be all right. You just do as I  say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes Samuel by the hand, leads him to the side door. bends, holds the boy close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let them hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising, pushing Samuel  toward door) I won't. Now run. (as Sam looks back) Fast as you can!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam turns, takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fergie almost to the upper barn, McElroy В– well back and moving slowly, circumspectly В– headed toward the lower b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book, at another window in the lower barn, sees McElroy  heading for the milkhouse door. He can't see Fergie. He t crosses the cowpen area, climbs an inner ladder leading t the upper barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fergie at the door to the upper barn, moving very cautiou gun up. He eases around the doorpost, looks within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond Book, now at the top of the ladder, we see Fergie  easing into the barn. Book pulls himself up, crawls behin the wall of the mule stalls, opens gate, eases in beside  Luke, urgently whispering and patting the animal to calm  him. He gets to the animal's head, crouches, strokes Luke nose. The mule's huge flanks quiver, his nostril's and ey widen, but he makes no untoward sound. Book closes the ga

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO FERGIE
dialogues.text: He comes on warily, muzzle first, eyes darting. DOLLYING WITH him as he reaches the first mule's stall, o the gate. An edgy mule turns, eyes him, shuffles nervousl Fergie backs off, moves on.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: As he listens, tenses, hearing Fergie's feet in the fresh straw. Book eases back alongside Luke, waits.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO FERGIE
dialogues.text: As he approaches Luke's stall, reaches for the gate-latch

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: As the gate swings open, Book shouts and gives Luke a wha on the back. The mule's pent-up nerves and feral energy  explode in an horrendous SCREAM.

dialogues.speaker: FERGIE
dialogues.text: Bowled backwards by the rearing animal as the gate flies  open, involuntarily FIRING, suddenly finding himself unde the lethal hooves of a twelve-hundred pound beast. Stagge backwards, he SCREAMS, FIRES again, the load striking the mule in its heaving chest as a flailing hoof smashes into Fergie's head and the other hoof snaps his shotgun in hal like a matchstick.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: As he slips out of the stall, ducks toward the rear of th barn.

dialogues.speaker: FERGIE
dialogues.text: Fallen, skull smashed... and now the dying Luke's legs bu and he collapses atop Fergie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McElroy standing still, shock-eyed, looking toward the so of the shots. Then starting slowly forward.

dialogues.speaker: SCHAEFFER
dialogues.text: On the porch of the house, looking toward the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some distance from the barn, Samuel's hearing the shots,  stops dead in his tracks... the sound of the shots still  REVERBERATING across the quiet fields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stricken) Mr. Book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hesitates, then turns, starts trotting back toward the barns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel has moved into the open kitchen door, glances anxi toward the barns. Starts out. Schaeffer pushes her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son is out there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's going to hurt your son...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As McElroy, checking the safety on his twelve-gauge, step into the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McElroy flattens himself against the wall, looks around  fearfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Fergie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaeffer staring toward the barn, SHOUTS:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He listens, hears nothing, snorts, starts toward the barn checking his gun, not hurrying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli now seated at the table, holding a cloth to his head. Rachel at a window, peering out. Schaeffer on the porch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel running as fast as he can trips as he crosses a sm muddy stream, falls full length, scrambles up, runs on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McElroy, moving very cautiously, comes around the mule st stops short, stares off screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where he lies half buried beneath the huge bulk of the mu his head crushed like an eggshell.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO MCELROY
dialogues.text: As he moves on around Fergie and the dead mule, planting  each foot as if he were walking in a mine field.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: Standing in shadow at the back of the barn next to a hay  mow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving toward the center of the barn.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: As he starts to move even further back, he nudges into a  rope fastened to the wall behind him, He looks at it, loo up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It runs from where it is fastened to the wall straight up the center roofbeam of the barn to a trolley fixed to a t that runs the length of the roofbeam. Attached to this tr is a big hayfork (Paul Krantz has one), U-shaped, sharply pointed at each end of the U. the points hanging toward t floor. The thing weighs about eighty pounds, and is suspe in place by the rope anchored at the wall next to Book.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BOOK
dialogues.text: Keeping one eye on McElroy, he carefully begins to un-tie the trip rope.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Moving out toward the center of the barn, almost under th suspended hay fork. He stops short, listens. Then, either spotting a moving shadow or hearing a SOUND, he FIRES. Hi shot rattles off the side of a manure spreader. He SHOUTS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book, you sneaky bastard, I know  you're here! Come out and fight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel, at the top of the barnyard, stops at the SOUND OF THE SHOT, wide-eyed. He listens for an-instant, starts a  step toward the barn, then stops again, looks to a large  bell suspended in a cupola by one of the outbuildings. He moves quickly to the bell, seizes the rope, pulls. The be CLANGS loudly, Sonorously.

dialogues.speaker: SCHAEFFER
dialogues.text: On the front porch, looking around for the location of th sounding bell. He takes a step toward the barn, the stops looks back toward the house... frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book watches as McElroy starts to move again looking back toward the SOUNDING of the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking down we can see McElroy almost directly beneath t hay fork. The bell SOUNDING throughout. BOOK Waiting... t rope in hand. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Hey, Mac!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he lets go the trip rope.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: As he turns toward the SOUND of Book's voice.

dialogues.speaker: HAY FORK
dialogues.text: As it plummets down, causing a RATCHETING SOUND that fill the barn, even drowns out the SOUND of the bell.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Eyes darting wildly, looking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plunging straight for him.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Diving to one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUDDING into the barn floor like a great trident fork. Quivering there, not a foot from McElroy's head.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Staring at the fork pop-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: Sprinting toward a ladder thrust up through an opening in the barn floor just in front of his parked car.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Spotting Book, coming up to one knee, quick-aiming, FIRIN The shot smashes the windshield of the car.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: Diving, rolling, slamming into the top of the ladder, fla down out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: FIRING AGAIN, then again. Emptying the gun, cursing as he begins to reload, gets to his feet, starts toward the lad The BELL still SOUNDING outside. The hood of the car SLOW POPS UP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As McElroy wheels at the movement of the car's hood, FIRE twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The buckshot virtually blows the dashboard off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel RINGING the bell. The bell rope is short, and so i Samuel and his feet go off the ground with every swing of the rockerarm. He hangs on grimly, his black hat clinging to the back of his head, his face set against the tears that move down h cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: SCHAEFFER
dialogues.text: Comes hesitantly down the path toward the barn, looking t the sound of the bell, but also looking back in glances t the house to make sure Rachel and Eli stay where they are He still can't see Samuel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Rachel starts off the porch, takes a few steps.

dialogues.speaker: SCHAEFFER
dialogues.text: Turning, SHOUTING:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stay put!

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: She stops. She is also unable to see Samuel.

dialogues.speaker: SCHAEFFER
dialogues.text: Moving out toward the barn, rounding a corner... and ther is Samuel at the bellrope. He starts toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond Samuel, well out in the fields of the Stoltzfus fa Stotlzfus and others В– including Hochstetler and his bro В– are baling the first cutting of June hay. But the operation has come to a halt. All are looking in  toward the Lapp farm, hearing the RINGING OF THE BELL (th Amish cry for help), wondering, hesitating. But now, as we watch, led by Hochstetler, they start in t Samuel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Schaeffer reaches Samuel, SHOUTS:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut that out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel looks at him, keeps on pulling. Schaeffer quickly crosses to him, grabs him by the back o the neck, tries to pull him off the bell rope. Samuel han on grimly. Schaeffer yanks hard, succeeds in yanking Samuel free, sh him roughly aside. Then Schaeffer turns, FIRES a shotgun  blast into the top of the bellrope. It still hangs by sev threads, so he FIRES again. The rope drops to the ground. Schaeffer reloads, turns to look at Samuel, just getting to his feet. A moment... whe Schaeffer, recognizing Samuel as the Amish kid who saw Mc kill Zenovich, perhaps thinks of disposing of the witness right then and there. But a glance toward the oncoming Amish gives him pause. H SNARLS at Sam:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get down to the house and stay there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Samuel gets to his feet, turns, trots off.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Already halfway out to the barn, running to gather Sam in her arms... then to lead him back toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: SCHAEFFER
dialogues.text: Turning, starting very slowly toward the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McElroy at the top of the ladder, looking down. Then easi over, placing his feet on the rungs.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: He stands below in a cowpen, using the cows for cover. Th cows stare balefully at him. A large goat nuzzles him, ho at him with its horns. Book waits, watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visible to his knees as he eases down the ladder. He stop at every rung to scrape his shoes free of the cowshit cov the rungs.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BOOK
dialogues.text: He turns now to a door at the back of the pen. He un-hook it, pulls it open, moves inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is now in a small passageway giving on to the entrance a nearly-empty silo. Above the entrance, a ladder (interi rises to the top of the structure. Book looks in, and up. We should get the impression that  Book's been here before, expects what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty feet up, a patch of blue sky through an open hatch.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BOOK
dialogues.text: He steps through to the base of the ladder, then ducks be it into the silo. There is about two feet of old silage  covering the floor. He turns, looks up the white walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An inside ladder runs to the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing against the wall next to the entrance... . obvio to be inserted as the silo is filled.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: Now, quickly, he ducks back out through the entrance, cro to the door to the cowpen, very cautiously peers out..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McElroy at the bottom of the ladder, looking in the other direction (toward the milkhouse).

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BOOK
dialogues.text: Very carefully he shoves the cowpen door (which opens out into the cowpen). It begins to swing very slowly open. Bo immediately turns, darts back into the silo.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Turning slowly toward the cowpen... then FIRES twice as h eye catches the motion of the swinging door. His shots bl half a row of Eli's precious tools off an adjacent wall.  McElroy reloads, starts across toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Eli, at the sight of Samuel, rises from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Praise Gott!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel stands aside as the old man embraces Samuel long a hard. She watches as he turns to the cupboard, takes down the b family Bible. He crosses to the table, sets the book down places his hand on its pulls Samuel to the table beside h Rachel holds another beat as she stares at the old man  helplessly, then she rushes to where she hid Book's gun,  takes it down... her trembling hands take the bullets out the coffee jar. She drops several as she tries to figure how to open the chamber to load it. In the b.g., Eli glances up, sees what she is about... he rises and crosses to her. Samuel watches from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fiercely) No, Rachel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to help him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel somehow manages to open the chamber and begins to to load the bullets. Eli's callused hand closes over hers halting the action:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not our way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullets are already CLATTERING to the floor from her trem fingers as she raises her eyes to Eli's. A long beat as Rachel looks at him... Finally her fingers release the pistol and it CLATTERS to the floor. She clos her eyes. Samuel, who has gotten up, moved to a window, watches Eli and Rachel silently. Eli leads her to the table, places her hands on the Bible beneath his. They stand there and they pray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book finishes putting the kickboard into the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Moving among the cows, stepping cautiously between the  cowflops. The goat nudges him once, then butts him rather firmly.  McElroy swats at him with the gun butt, moves to the door As he arrives, he HEARS a noise В– very slight В– from th direction of the silo. He enters the passage way, looks in toward the silo entra He hesitates. Another slight noise. He steps in to the ba of the inner ladder, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patch of blue sky, forty feet up.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO MCELROY
dialogues.text: He frowns, reaches out, grabs a rung.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaeffer, easing toward the mule stalls, MUTTERS, CURSES under his breath. Then he rounds the corner of the first  stall... and there is Fergie with Luke the mule on top of him. Schaeffer stares, blinks... moves on spotting a spen shotgun shell near the hayfork...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book listening at the kickboard. SOUNDS of feet, shotgun  rattling against metal rungs, Book moves to the ladder on his side, starts silently up.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Climbing with difficulty, shotgun clutched in one hand.

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: He climbs up to the second kickboard, pauses, checks the  distance to the floor, starts upward again.

dialogues.speaker: BARN YARD
dialogues.text: The Amish beginning to arrive. Sam comes running, pulls  Stoltzfus toward the door of the milkhouse as the other A look at the shot-shattered bellrope. Rachel and Eli come  rapidly up the path toward the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaeffer finds another spent shotgun shell, crosses to t ladder, looks down. He sets his shotgun down, takes out h service revolver, starts down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Book has reaches the third kickboard, about thirty feet f the ground. He checks it, turns the thumb-screws that hol it in place, places his hand on the handle, moves to one  side as best he can... hangs there, listening.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
dialogues.text: Rattling up the other ladder, approaching the third kickb

dialogues.speaker: BOOK
dialogues.text: Listening tensely, hearing McElroy arrive on the other si of the kickboard. Then, deliberately, Book makes a fist,  raps on the board smartly once.

dialogues.speaker: MCELROY
